pros:

Great first experience in banking, and the concierge position empowered me and gave me a clear path to how I could become a Personal Banker in the future
cons:
(As a pre-word, many of these points likely apply to many of the other major banking institutions in the US as well)
Corporate obviously cuts costs at every opportunity, and the current CEO's changes have driven many people, including senior employees with decades of experience at Citi, to other institutions. Branch employees were expected to work during the pandemic, often without a branch manager, but without pay increases, either to adjust for the risk of in-person work or even just an adjustment for overall inflation during COVID.
Cost cutting means that clients have seemed to not always come first in terms of corporate's priorities. The systems are heavily unreliable, with lots of incompatible technology that seldom seems to work. Corporate says the solution to everything is usually in the Source, which is the database referenced when helping customers. Often, the solution is not in the Source, and clients end up frustrated without many answers.
Citi Customer Service was always sending clients into the branch, saying that we could help them with things we had no control over. This is probably a result of miscommunication to the customer service representatives.
The customer satisfaction surveys don't make any sense. Employees are held to a standard based on "Net Promoters", which refers to people who score the service as a 10/10, or 100%. Each survey that is 9 or below counts as a 0% score, with 0 resulting in a negative percentage. Branches were judged based on the monthly average, but this would often not reflect our actual performance because lots of people just don't give 10s on principle. What this means is we provide great service, get recognized for our competence in the client's review in word, but a score of 9 counts as a 0 and we are punished (usually in the form of a negligible annual pay raise, with the justification of being an "under-performing" branch.
